prompt: What is an operating model for AI?
label:
It refers to the processes put in place to work with AI, from use case definition, to development to deployment and operation. Ultimately the objective of an operating model for AI is to streamline the value generation process from data to business results. Developing AI applications is a highly iterative process and generally strives in an agile environment.  However, organisations operate in a wide variety of contexts and come in many different shapes and sizes, hence it makes sense that there is no universal operating model for AI that fits everywhere. Regulatory requirements, data and resource availability and many other factors will play a role in determining the right operating model. 

It is important then, to have a platform that is able to scale with the organisation as more use cases and users enter the pipeline, as more models are deployed and as more of the business is enhanced by data and AI. The services that underpin the operating model need to be flexible while at the same time ensuring that security and explainability permeate every step of the process.
output: A high performing operating model  is the glue that helps your organization effectively use AI by adopting the right structure, processes, people, technology and culture to implement and continuously improve on your use of AI. Your operating model describes how AI capabilities, processes, data and people will work together as an ecosystem so your organization can focus on the business outcome you’re trying to improve. The operating model is adaptable, customized for your organization, has high level standards and low level details specific to your industry/domain, is data and automation enabled, focuses on outcomes and agility, has built in monitoring and governing components to allow for continuous monitoring and improvement. The people aspect of your operating model focuses on skills, knowledge and roles to support the implementation and use of AI; process, data and technology addresses how to implement and continuously improve use of AI; and security and governance ensure AI capabilities and associated data and processes are trusted.

An operating model for AI is how a company plans to operate in order to deploy and maintain their AI assets (tools, data, models, results). These models can reside in software or on human operators. The operating model includes the workflow from the initial business problem recognition, the sourcing and collection of data to train, the development and training of AI models and deployment. These AI models may generate outputs such as predictions or automated actions. It also considers the workflow around operationalising AI models after they are built such as monitoring data and model performance, model maintenance and the creation of dashboards that explain the AI models’ outputs. 
It is important to standardise how an organisation operates AI, it helps maintain a repeatable workflow, reduce errors and increase trust in the AI models generated outputs.

An operating model for AI describes the structure and processes necessary to integrate artificial intelligence successfully into an organisation. Effective management of an AI ecosystem also depends on clear definition of responsibility for data, assets, models, deployment, use and governance. In order to ensure long-term use of AI, the operating model should define the required organisational setups, including structure, roles, responsibilities, metrics as well as information flow and the integration of AI platforms and tools.
Defining an operating model for AI requires aligning an organization’s AI strategy with people, processes, data and technology. An effective AI operating model is a continuous and iterative process.

prompt: What is linear programming and how to solve?
label:
Linear programming is a method to achieve the best objective in an optimization problem whose objective function and requirements are represented by linear relationships. The simplex method and the interior-point method are common algorithms to solve linear programming problems.

You can visit https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming to learn more.
output: Linear programming is method to optimize a linear objective function under linear constraints. The variables in the linear programming is represented by x, y or z.

Linear programming (LP or L.P.) is a method to achieve the best objective in an optimization problem whose objective function and requirements are represented byLinear programming constraints.The objective function can be maximized or minimized and its type will determine the constraints of the problem to include in the simplex. The simplex method described below can solve either Linear Programming Problem (LPP or LP) strictly better in expectation (i.e., it is an equilibrium algorithm), but only approximates the solution to the Mixed Label 0 - Integer Programming Problem (M LP 0/1).
Linear Programming (Simple) is a relaxation method that starts with the Integral Linear Programming (ILP) solution if one exists, and can produce the global solution if the problem has a single extremum. The integer-toeld solutions(Cut) algorithm, which does not detect this property, has solved some LP instances which do not have any integer solutions, though the current strong LP bound on it states that for any given LP bound on the integrality gap it makes only a polynomial effort to improve the cut bound unless the current integralities have integer solutions that form at most an lp-polynomial blowup of the basic iron ore in the

Linear programming is best method to achieve the best result in resource allocation problems. Linear Programming problems are associated with constraints, in which only linear relationships between constraints are allowed and the objective is to maximise (or minimise) the objective value. A simplex based interior-point method is used to solve the linear programming problems.

Linear programming is a method to achieve the best objective in an optimization problem whose objective function and requirements are represented by linear relationships. There are interior-point methods for solving simplex-free linear programming problems in a relatively affordable amount of time. In extreme cases (fee simplelinear programs), a non-convex and non-deterministic relaxation of the binary integer program may be constructed, whose global optimal solution is guaranteed under certain hypotheses. One of the most popular semidefinite programming algorithms solves binary linear programs via alternating minimization with the simplex algorithm for discrete variables. Various interior-point and active-set methods are available for solving general linear programs. There exist algorithms for specific types of integer programming problems which are very efficient when those special forms are present.

prompt: Why use an ereader to read a book?
label:
Using an electronic reader over a book has many advantages. You have immediate access to large libraries of books. You can purchase and start reading a new book in minutes. You can also take your entire library with you when you travel without lugging around many or large books. E-readers also give the ability to read in the dark without using other lighting that may disturb those around you.

While tablets have many of these same benefits, the experience on ereaders is better for reading books. The screens cause much less eye strain due to the use of electron inc on many of the devices. They are also free from notifications and other distractions found on tablets and smartphones.
output: There are many benefits to using an ereader instead of the usual paperback or hardcover books. For one, it frees up space in your bag or home and also reduces weight of carrying a lot of books. Since ereaders store the contents online, there is immediate availability of books without needing to carry multiple copies. If the book is out of copyright, you can often borrow ebooks from your local library to read on your ereader without needing to physically go to the library. Another benefit is that when many versions of a book are available, ereaders often allow you to search throughout the whole text to find all occurrences of a word, unlike paperbacks.

An e-reader provides an easy, convenient way to read.  You purchase a book through the device or through an associated app, and can quickly and easily get reading.   No more physical bookshelf clutter in your home and easier to purchase and take with you large collections of books since you are not purchasing physical books.  You can also use lights or blue filters to help your reading and reduce eye strain as you do not have the normal overhead from reading physical books for several hours a day.

Using an ebook reader comes with many benefits and some potential downsides:
Pros
- Your library of ebooks can be stored on a single small device (reader or tablet/phone) and does not take up any physical space
- The electronic ink based readers are often very light which makes them easy to hold for a long time
- There are no pages to turn, and if the books are purchased through a service such as Google Books or Kindle, no need to flip through pages to get to the start of a new chapter as table of contents is available with just a few clicks.
- You can carry an entire library in the device which fits into a small handbag (depending on the size of the device and the library)

Cons
- If using an ebook reader and not used to the display technology it might take some getting used to as the electronic ink black-and-white display is starkly different than a true-color tablet/phone

In summary, using an ebook reader is highly dependent on 
1. how familiar the user is with the reader display tech
2. how large the reader library is compared to the storage space available on the reader (if a

Reading a book on an ereader offers many benefits.  
First, it allows you to carry an almost infinite amount of books in a small unit.    
Second, it is significantly lighter than carrying multiple books with you.
Third, there is no need to hold out your hand to use a kindle ereader to "page" through the book.   
Fourth, you can also search for key words, find related books of the same author, view related books that other people are reading as well as see a full book summary with a single click of the click all from within the reader.

prompt: What is Occam's razor?
label: Occam’s razor is a principle of theory construction or evaluation according to which, other things equal, explanations that posit fewer entities, or fewer kinds of entities, are to be preferred to explanations that posit more. It is sometimes misleadingly characterized as a general recommendation of simpler explanations over more complex ones.

More broadly, it is the adoption of the explanation of any item that posits the least count of entities (entailed by 'no unnecessary assumption' in earlier versions of William of Ockham's formulation). It is an a prioriori (having to do with reasoning from causality) and not a posteriori reasoning (requiring new data).

The principle states that, other things equal, explanations with fewer entities (or terms, or concepts, or variables) are to be preferred to those with more. One should never multiply entities beyond necessity.

It says "Among competing hypotheses, the one with the fewest assumptions should be preferred." The phrase was popularized by William of Ockham, who lived in the 14th century, and the meaning has not changed in over seven centuries. However, in Ockham's time, it was part of a debate within theological hair-splitting - how many angels can dance on the head of a pin? Now, in the 21st century, it is part of our day-to-day life, from medicine to investing. As Ockham said, "It is always vain to do what may not be done."
The simplest explanation for why the sky is blue is that it's the reflection of sunlight. Occam's razor suggest that this should be the favorite explanation for the color we see in the sky.

prompt: How do you make a good cappuccino?
label:
There are multiple steps involved in making a good cappuccino:

Step 1: Find fresh coffee beans and grind them finely

For optimal taste, the coffee beans should be fresh and only slightly oxidized. It is important to use a high quality grinder that grinds the beans uniformly and finely. You should fill a portafilter with 18-21g of grounds and tamp the grounds.

Step 2: Pull the shot

Turn on the espresso machine, wait for it to heat up, and press the button to start the shot. The goal is to make ~40g of espresso in 25-30 seconds starting from when you initiated the pull.

Step 3: Steam the milk and pour

Pour milk into a carafe and use the steam wand to steam the milk. You want to aerate the milk, but not too much or too little. You want to avoid making macrobubbles and also heat up the milk so that the carafe is hot to the touch. Now pour the milk into the espresso, and you're done!
output:
A good cappuccino must use a high-quality shot of espresso to balance out the foamy top layer.
A good cappuccino begins with good milk. This milk is steamed to create microbubbles, ensuring that the cappuccino comes out smooth.
A good barista must use expert technique to balance the espresso and milk. The espresso should fill approximately half of the cup, and the milk should be spooned in with artistic flair on top to fill out the rest of the cup. The milk must also be poured with precise speed so that the froth gets distributed evenly on top.
But most important of all is that good cappuccinos come from heart. Great baristas pour from a passion for coffee-making. The joy they pour into every cup of coffee is felt by those who experience it.

Cappuccino recipe:
- Invest in a quality grinder. It's difficult to over-emphasize the importance of using a recently-resharpened metal flat-blade grinder. Few things spoil coffee quite as quickly as using a dull grinder. Dull grinders will result in a less-than-optimal ratio of coffee to milk flavors.
- Use freshly-roasted and coarsely-ground coffee (20% and above) in your porta-filter; an ideal medium-coarse grind is too thick to fit through an Italian-style (pump) espresso machine's steam screen, but still lets the water go through without any noticeable 'clogs'. 
- 30 grams (for 120 ML): 17 grams of finely-ground coffee from an ESE (Easy Serving Espresso) tamp, and 13 grams of finely-ground coffee in the 'lip' above the tamp. You want most of the flavor to come from the concentrated coffee grounds (in the ESE tamp). For even extraction and better scaling

There are a few ingredients which are very important for a good cappuccino: high quality coffee beans, proper coffee grind and fresh milk. If your local coffee shop is making you a bad coffee then it's probably the quality of ingredients and equipment they are using which is to blame. It's also important to note that different coffee beans produce vastly different flavour notes; so you may need to choose the right coffee bean for the kind of taste you want to produce. This is a much more nuanced area then most people would expect but having good coffee beans is an important first step to making a good cappuccino.

Make espresso shots. In order to make an excellent shot of espresso you must pull 20 grams of medium or fine-grind coffee beans at a consistant flow rate for 25-30 seconds at 15 psi. After filling your espresso machine's portafilter, wipe away any excess coffee oils with a clean shop towel and then fill the portafilter with the appropriate amount of ground coffee. Make sure to level the grounds when loading the portafilter, this will increase your chances of achieving an excellant shot of espresso.
When you have your espresso shot pulled, use that rich, delicious shot of espresso to steam and froth your milk using a steam wand fitted to your espresso machine. Steam the milk for 5-10 seconds to achieve a silky-smooth texture and at the same time holding the bottom of the cup of milk with the frothed milk mixture pour the frothed espresso into a cup, and voila! A delicious cappuccino is finished.

Tennis leg -- also known as "tennis leg", "golfer's back syndrome" and "pocket hole" -- is a condition typically associated with tennis and/or golf in which the outside of the right (or left) leg, above the knee, becomes tender to the touch.  This condition has historically been thought by some medical professionals to be "a nuisance symptom with no known cause", however many medical professionals and sports experts believe that the cause is most likely related to some combination of overuse and/orial stress and repetitive motion; others believe that the cause could be attributed to other stress related factors such as poor or worn out tennis shoes, improper stringing of a tennis racket, and some believe it could be caused by playing on courts with irregular "pocket" areas where a person might repeatedly drop their feet.

prompt: What is data engineering?
label: Data engineering deals with building systems and process that bring data together and serve that data up to the business.  They ingest data, transform, data, apply data quality rules, and prepare finalized cleaned datasets for use by the business to get insights.  Data engineers have to be strong developers as well if data engineering has to be done using a programming language like Python.
output:
A subfield of data science, data engineering focuses on the building and maintenance of data systems and databases, including design, construction, testing, deployment, and performance monitoring of these systems. An data engineer's work is typically operational in nature and involves working with large data sets and various technologies to collect, transform, and load data into various databases and data warehouses.

In the past, organizations might have relied on a single enterprise data warehouse to collect and report information from their organization. Modern data architecture, however, often incorporates dozens of analytics and reporting systems in the form of data lakes, data marts, and data warehouses from a mix of different vendors, in addition to a myriad of data sources and other "source" systems. In many cases, these additional systems may not provide straightforward direct data access, and so organizations require a data engineering capability in order to collect, transform and load the data into an analytic or reporting system. As a result, data engineering has become an important role within many organizations. In organizations that have implemented a data warehouse-oriented data architecture, data engineers typically play an important role in constructing and maintaining

Data engineering is a process to transform an organization's data by building an infrastructure that allows data to be ingested, transformed, and analysed in an timely fashion so it can support a data rich organization. The data processing needed is often beyond simple data aggregations and involves using statistical methods, and using different kinds of algorithmic techniques that apply statistical theory and practice such as hypothesis testing to the problem of data processing to allow you to build models with much higher precision on a statistically significant basis over a much larger dataset scale needed to gain the level of trust in the analysis required by modern analytic users (which can be measured as the amount of predicted business outcome which is the revenue that your dashboard drives). This results in dashboards and associated model driven reporting applications and alerts which in turn enable the organisation to achieve its goals by changing the way it interacts with its users based on the factual predictive outcomes of realtime predictive model-based applications running on top of a large volume of trustworthy structured, semi-structured and even unstructured data in all its forms in one single integrated system architecture. Data Engineers design and create the pipelines, process workflows and underlying database structures that data flows through.

Data engineering occurs at the process layer of the data lifecycle and is concerned with building systems that deliver, transform, and deliver data (extract-transform-load, ETL/ELT) for analysis.  Data engineers make large volumes of data ready for analysis at an economic scale by designing databases, optimizing queries, and building automated processes. Like a data analyst, they want to make the most of the data they already have, but their focus is scaling to petabyte-level databases and ensuring performance in queries that reference the entirety of the data. Like a data scientist, they ensure that their models see the relevant data and get trustworthy answers about customers, operations, and more. In general, a data engineer has to balance scalability and performance versus data quality. Scalability/performance trumps quality 80% of the time (thousands to millions of flows, tens to hundreds of thousands of consumers), with small amounts of 100% quality data guaranteed for the occasional flows / dashboards / customer requests.

It is a process for building data pipelines that delivers trusted and scalable data to the organization. This is done with an automated and repeatable process for designing, building, executing, delivering, and maintaining data pipelines, and Data Catalog that automatically collects metadata from data pipelines and builds a searchable catalog of all the data in an organization.

prompt: What is Hornachuelos?

output: Hornachuelos is a town in the province of Cádiz, in the autonomous community of Andalusia, Spain. It is situated in the mountainous southern region of the province, and like many Andalusian villages, it has a rich history that can be seen in its many remains from various historical periods. prompt: How did the Royal Navy Protect the British Task Force from Argentine air attacks during the Falklands War?
label: The British managed to minimize their shipping losses through a combination of layered air defenses and signals intelligence. Type 42 destroyers and Sea Dart missiles provided adequate high-altitude air defense, forcing Argentine pilots to fly at very low altitudes to evade Royal Navy ship-based radar. Royal Navy submarines operating off the coast of Argentina could use electronic sensors in their periscopes to detect electronic signals from Argentine aircraft as they took off. These subs provided the fleet with enough advanced warning to launch Sea Harriers on interception missions. Consequently, an Argentine pilot needed to be ready to dogfight a Harrier, dodge surface-to-air missiles, and then pull off a low-level bombing run. All three of these tasks required a level of training that most Argentine pilots lacked. Argentina ran out of fighter jets before the British ran out of ships.

The British quickly learned in the early stages of the Falklands War that Argentina's antiquated air force lacked the radar technology needed to locate ships on the open ocean. They also understood it would be too dangerous for Argentine pilots to risk shooting down in the open water and too small for Argentine fighter jets to locate. Consequently, the Brits stationed destroyers at the mouth of the Port of Stanley which allowed the Brits to identify the aircraft before it could launch. Once the Argentine pilots aborted their missions, they were easy pickings for British jet fighters that patrolled the skies. All of these factors effectively neutralized Argentina's airforce and the Brits were able to sail their ships close to the coastline whenever they pleased for the remainder of the war.

In order to protect the British Task Force from attacks by Argentine naval vessels and aircraft, the Royal Navy used a number of tactics.  They included putting their ships and planes at reduced readiness (i.e., not “horizon to horizon”, that is, completely operational), deploying Sea Harriers as helicopter killers, and the destroyer, HMS Glamorgan putting radar decoy (radar dishes) above its 5 inch gun mounts.  Above all, the British learned how to better recognize, target, and counter Argentine aviation.  While British aircraft did shoot down several Argentine Air Force planes, and HMS Glamorgan damaged one, it was actually the Sea Harriers which did the most important work of defending the Task Force.

output: Quarks are elementary subatomic particles that are classified as fermions. They make up the matter in the universe and are the smallest particles for which the Standard Model of elementary particle physics can account. Quarks are "fermions" and come in two families: one comprising the u, c and t quarks (called up, down, and strange quarks), and a second family comprising the d, s and b quarks (called down, strange, and bottom quarks), both of which interact via the strong subatomic force. A third family, known as charm quarks, and sometimes regarded as a second set of down quarks, appears in high-energy physics where quarks interact via the strong interactions via the strong–weak interaction symmetry, and interacts with gluons via glueballs and with other particles, such as W and Z bosons, via vector boson conversion processes. These three families of quarks can form eight types of hadrons via the strong interaction, which makes quarks one of the fundamental particles of which matter is composed.

These hypothetical particles were later discovered in the 1960's at physically relevant energies.

Exactly six types of quarks exist. They have been observed experimentally and are categorized by their intrinsic properties and behavior, such as how they interact with each other or with radiation.

The word "quark" is borrowed from a term invented by John D. Rodker in his 1969 short story The Word for World is Forest, where it designated a monetary unit, a small stack of which could be taken as change from a gavige, and large stacks of which were used for trade.

In the sense of a small amount, usage of the word currency began around 1985 by graduate students on the Stony Brook University campus and spread rapidly through local students after the idea that the word "quark" could be used to refer the smallest units of currency was codified in L. prompt: What is an architecture diagram?

They are a represented with different shapes, words, lines are arrows that show the visual flow. Architecture diagrams show different views of high-level design of the architecture of a solution and are normally abstract. Architectural diagrams are intended to provide insight into the nature and structure of the systems rather than expose specific details.

Architecture diagrams usually consist of visual notations that are interpreted on the basis of established semantics which can vary slightly across different notations. 
They are important in complex domains like software development, urban planning, process management or safety-critical systems to provide a shared understanding across all participants in a project or a system of systems. 
When creating an architecture diagram, architects usually start from simple conceptual views based on driver needs that must be satisfied before they evolve into highly aggregated system architecture diagrams focussing on components involved in business processes.
The various views provided by architecture diagrams help architects in a planning role and stakeholders unfamiliar with the same semantics to understand an architecture based on use case views and an architect's own views that are based on an understanding of how systems evolve over time while catering to business drivers that underpin an enterprise architecture.

An architecture diagram or architectural diagram, sometimes known as an ARchitecture Diagram, is a visual, simplified representation of an enterprise (or part of an enterprise) targeted at a particular viewpoint. 
Diagrams can be used to represent different views on IT architectures, business processes, and organizational structure, to name a few. Enterprise architects, information architects, and business architects mainly use architectural diagrams. These diagrams make it easier to examine things holistically: all aspects that affect an architecture view are included in a high level of detail to support effective communication and planning. There should be a standard set of base elements in every architecture diagram, no matter the viewpoint. There are various architecture viewpoints and hence, multiple architecture diagrams will be created and maintained.

An architecture diagram is a visual graph that represents concepts, actors, systems, and business processes, all connected to each other and depicted as boxes and flowing arrows. The boxes represent Actors and Systems, and the flowing arrows depict the process activities, which can include data exchanges between systems, interactions between actors, and decisions and rule application. The relationships can be further annotated with notes or added explanations as necessary. The notation languages provide sets of standard symbols and conventions for drawing architecture diagrams so they are easy for anyone to understand.

prompt: What is the difference between an adverb and adjective?
label: An adjective describes an item, whereas an adverb modifies a verb
output: Most adjectives end in -er or -est, whereas adverbs generally don't. An adjective is describing an item. The sky is blue. Blue is an adjective describing the item 'sky'. An adverb is describing how a verb or another adverb is used. For example, quickly is an adverb describing the verb run in the sentence Jack runs quickly.

Adverbs generally provide information regarding how and to what extent something is true. A classic example is the difference between the adverbs very and very good. It is correct to describe someone as very kind, but if someone asks how good someone is at a particular task, that someone can only be described as good. Adverbs can also provide information regarding frequency. Words like often, frequently and regularly are examples of this.  Adjectives on the other hand provide information about what kind of description is being made. Words like nice and good are examples of adjectives, when used as describing words, they will describe the thing they are describing. Nice is an adjective when used to describe the phrase very nice holiday.

Adverbs and adjectives might seem similar at first glance.  Their primary function is to describe other words or phrases. An adjective would modify a noun or pronoun whereas an adverb would modify a verb.  The difference, however, lies in their endsings. An adjective's form ends in -ly; for example, clever becomes cleverly. The verb ends in -ly does modify the stem of the verb, such as "walk" becoming "walkly." Walkly is not a regular verb though so don't try to use this in a sentence! An adverb is just the stem of the verb with no ending; therefore, walk becomes just "walk" which makes it an adverb itself and can be used in a sentence like: She walked with great walk which makes great an adjective to describe "walk".  

I hope that helps clarify the difference adverbs and adjectives for you!

1. Carcinoma - A type of cancer that begins in the epithelial cells, which are the cells that line the surfaces of the organs and glands. Examples of carcinoma types include colon cancer, breast cancer, and lung cancer.
2. Sarcoma - A type of cancer that starts in either connective or supportive tissue such as bone, cartilage, or fat. Sarcoma accounts for only 1% of cancers and examples include osteosarcoma (bone cancer), chondrosarcoma (bone and cartilage), and soft tissue sarcoma.
3. Myeloma - A type of cancer that results from an abnormal clumping of plasma cells. Myeloma cells can cause damage to bones, kidneys and the immune system.
In summary, different cancers have very different origins; some originate in the tissue layers, some in blood or connective tissue, and others in the immune

Charlie's love for golf was reignited when his Uncle Bob helped him realize it. His love for the game is a continued source of fulfillment and joy in the face of his untimely passing.

prompt: What is the main tax benefit of a Roth IRA and 401K?
label: The main tax benefit of a Roth IRA and 401K is that realized gains from selling investments within the accounts are not taxed.
output: All withdrawals are tax-free if held for more than five years.  One will pay taxes on the income while making contributions.  There are income restrictions on who is eligible to participate in a Roth IRA and 401K.  Income and contribution limits for individuals is $137k and up for married couples $200k and up.

Although there are various tax advantages and benefits to each retirement savings vehicle, the biggest difference between a Roth IRA and a traditional 401K (and other qualified plans) comes down to taxes in retirement.

Income taxes are due when a traditional IRA, 401K, and other qualified plans are withdrawn or retired. So if you withdraw $10,000 from your $100,000 IRA and 401K balances, you’ll be paying income taxes on $90,000.

Roth IRA distributions or withdrawals are not taxed because you already paid income taxes on the money going into the account. If you want to withdraw $10,000 from your $100,000 Roth IRA balance, you’ll only pay taxes on the $10,000 if you sold investments in the Roth IRA that have capital gains, but not income taxes on the $90,000 you didn’t sell because the balance is growing in value over time.

Most people will have a higher tax bra

Both the Roth IRA and 401K offer tax benefits.   A Roth IRA and 401K contributions are made with after tax dollars so the investments grow tax free, and when withdrawn as qualified withdrawals in retirement are tax free.   Nonqualified withdrawals are subject to taxes.  Contributions to a 401K are tax deductible, and withdrawals in retirement are considered tax free.

All gains on the investments made within these tax advantaged retirement accounts will be completely free of federal income tax if certain conditions are met at the time the assets are withdrawn in retirement.

prompt: What is paella?
label: Paella is a dish that is very popular in Spain. It is made of rice, saffron, and usually comes with fish or chicken.
output: Paella is a traditional spanish dish, in general it could be considered as a rice dish with saffron, but there are many varieties in the recipe. There are seafood paella, chicken paella, rabbit paella and so on.

Paella (Spanish pronunciation: [paˈeля]) is a traditional dish that originated in Spain and consists mainly of rice, usually white, along with other ingredients that may include fish or other seafood, shellfish, chicken, saffron, and spices. There are several variations of this dish. The rice used in Paella has grains that are larger than those used for other Asian or Hispanic types of rice.

Paella is a dish typical of the Valencia region in Eastern Spain.  Combining both an ingredient and a way to cook it is, in our modern language, considered a "dish", and thus not a recipe for that specific dish.  Cooked in a large skillet and typically made at a outdoor, large, community gathering known as a "paellera" paella is a delicacy, a dish fit for the king, and considered the number one signature dish from the Iberian peninsula.  Using rice, of which the Valencians are responsible for growing and processing more than any other country or region in the world.  With Spain being the largest importer of rice worldwide to have Paella without saffron is considered a blasphemy of the highest nature

Paella is a traditional dish that originates from the Valencia region in Spain. Typically cooked over an open flame, Paella Valenciana, is usually mildly seasoned with saffron and contains chicken, rabbit, snails, and/or shrimp. However, the most popular paella dish in America is paella española, or Spanish Paella, which only contains chicken and usually includes clams. The dish consists of long-grain rice, which has been saffroned and cooked in a spice blend called “romesco” (this can replace or accompany the traditional saffron in more modern or simplified recipes) mixed with seafood or chicken. Apart from the protein (which can sometimes be replaced with vegetarian stock), the only else needed for a proper paella is “arroz Bomba,” which is long-grain rice from theValencia region or risotto-style rice fromItaly.

prompt: What is the US Congress
label:
The United States Congress is the legislature of the federal government of the United States. It is bicameral, composed of a lower body, the House of Representatives, and an upper body, the Senate. It meets in the U.S. Capitol in Washington, D.C. Senators and representatives are chosen through direct election, though vacancies in the Senate may be filled by a governor's appointment. Congress has 535 voting members: 100 senators and 435 representatives. The U.S. vice president has a vote in the Senate only when senators are evenly divided. The House of Representatives has six non-voting members.

The sitting of a Congress is for a two-year term, at present, beginning every other January. Elections are held every even-numbered year on Election Day. The members of the House of Representatives are elected for the two-year term of a Congress. The Reapportionment Act of 1929 established that there be 435 representatives, and the Uniform Congressional Redistricting Act requires that they be elected from single-member constituencies or districts. It is also required that the congressional districts be apportioned among states by population every ten years using the U.S. census results, provided that each state has at least one congressional representative. Each senator is elected at-large in their state for a six-year term, with terms staggered, so every two years approximately one-third of the Senate is up for election. Each state, regardless of population or size, has two senators, so currently, there are 100 senators for the 50 states.
output: The United States Congress is the legislative branch of the federal government. It is bicameral, composed of a lower body, the House of Representatives, and an upper body, the Senate. Together, they make and pass laws that apply all 50 states. Members are elected to Congress every other year in elections which take place on even numbered years. Members of the House of Representatives are limited to 3 terms which is equivalent to 6 years in total. Senators have no term limits but elections every 2 years (an even-numbered year, i.e., 2022, 2024, etc.) means each Senator serves a half-term (6 years)
The United States Congress is the legislative branch of the federal government.

- Consist of the Senate and House of Representatives
- Senate has two members from each state for a total of 100 members and must include two from the Vice President as he/she casts tie breaking votes
- House of Representatives has a minimum of 1 and a maximum of 5510 members based on population of each state as reflected in the US Census.  
 - US Constitution grants the US Congress exclusively legislative powers

prompt: Why should I change my car oil?
label: Changing your car's engine oil is important for the engine's performance and longevity. The oil plays a critical role in engine operation, by providing lubrication between metal surfaces. Without oil, these surfaces will rub against one another and cause permanent damage and unrecoverable damage to the engine. Always use the engine oil type that is suggested by your car's manufacturer, and change the oil at the suggested interval. For many modern cars, this is either every 12 months or after 5000 to 10000 miles, whichever come first.
output:
Most vehicles come with the recommendation to change the oil every few thousand miles, typically in the range of 3,000-5,000 miles.

prompt: Give me some strategies to prevent procrastination

Procrastination is a huge problem for individuals in today's society. Though there are many strategies to beat procrastination, the effectiveness of these strategies is largely dependent on the individual and his/her/their circumstances. Here are some popular strategies to beat procrastination:

1. Set realistic, specific, and time-bound goals. The best goals should have some built-in time delays, but not too much, as to maintain some urgency. Large goals should also be broken into achievable chunks. 

2. Limit your access to distracting media. Making use of your device's focus modes, or locking away your device all together when working can prevent you from being distracted while executing tasks

3. Make the rewards of accomplishing goals tangible and more immediate. A popular strategy for this is temptation bundling, where you bundle a behavior that is good for you in the long-run with a behavior that feels good in the short-run. For example, you may only allow yourself to watch YouTube videos while you are folding laundry.

4. Use support systems. Often, using peers, family, or other individuals in your support system to help hold you accountable is an effective way to encourage task accomplishment. This method also promotes social interaction and continuous discussion of goals with others. As a caveat, you should not become reliant on this method, as it can create burdens on the other individuals in your support system

prompt: What are the typical items used to create a Haft-sin?

The traditional Haft-sin is comprised of Seven "S's": (Sefid, Sabzi, Samanu, Serkeh, Seemozooh, Somagh & Sugar) Here is a description of each one.

These are typically items you would find at a Persian-style tablesetting:
* Sabze: These are sprouts, usually little vines or herbs, growing in the ground
* Samanu: These are germinated wheat  and are usually soft and a bit chewy
* Serkeh: A sour drink made from vinegar, salt and herbs
* Kuchan: Boiled candy
* Seeb: Barley sprouts soaked in water
* Gheimeh-sabzi: Vegetable sprouts
* Adam: Wheat  sprouts growing in the ground
* Apples
* Coin
* Gold jewelry (typically a ring)
* Silver jewelry

All of the above items should be presented on the table in a decorative style; usually in nine sections mimicking the Haft-sin numbering. Each year they can vary what is included however the core always stay the same.

Traditionally items used to create a Haft-sin table setting are:
- Apples/Fruit - represents the tree of life. This item is removed by the next person when people gather around the table.
- Sweet pudding made from wheat sprouts known as Sugar Cane - represents good fortunes and richness
- Gold coins or money - represents wealth and riches
- Silver Coins - represents silver or wealth
- Salt - added one bite at a time represents the crying tears of Moses or the challenges and tribulations we face in life
- Parsley - grows back its green leaves after harvest time and winter represents hope of getting back to better conditions every year.
- Sumac (Nature's crackers) - prevents infection
- Venison (goat meat) - good meat, strength and happiness
- Barberry - for medicinal purposes
- Blanched almonds - strength 
- Bleru (wheat sprout) - life

prompt: Why do people get sore after working out?
label:
Muscle soreness occurs because muscle and the connective tissue around it get damaged during exercise, such as weight lifting or high intensity training. This kind of natural breakdown is natural and needed for muscle growth, since muscle grows back stronger during the body's repair process. During this process the affected muscle fibers increase in strength and thickness. 

Additionally, people tend to experience lactic acid buildup prior to exercise as your body uses oxygen to convert glucose to energy. During exercise, if there is a lack of oxygen for this process, you may produce a substance called lactate. Many people believe that soreness comes from the buildup of this lactic acid, but the real contributor is the breakdown of muscle from usage.
output: Muscle soreness occurs after your body breaks down its previously formed muscle fibers in your worked out muscle groups and rebuilds them with even stronger fibers. This rebuild muscle process needs oxygen, nutrients and minerals, which comes with blood into the muscle. Muscle soreness typically worsens the first couple of days after exercise then decreases and peaks between day 48 and 72 after the exercise starts to taper.

Muscle soreness, also know as Delayed Onset Muscle Soreness (DOMS), is very common after beginning an exercise program, or increasing exercise intensity or volume. This is completely normal, and the muscles are simply adapting and becoming more robust because they are being called upon to perform the movement more frequently and or with more force. Proper warming up, stretching, and getting sufficient sleep and nutrition are helpful in mitigating or preventing it.
When you workout, your body breaks down in various forms, including muscles fibers. So your muscles recover in order to get bigger, stronger, better next time!

Muscles in the body contract to perform physical labor. On occasions after a workout people's muscles are sore because those muscles expanded and contracted a lot more than usual and thus became weak temporarily, similar to how a rubber band becomes stretched out and weak after being used to lift very heavy things but becomes stronger and able to lift more weight than before after recovering. The same thing happens to people - the muscles become sore after contracting and expanding more than usual and then become stronger than before after recovering.

prompt: What's the most important thing in a marriage?

It's also important to remember that what work for other couples or whatever the social norms are may not apply for you, and that is ok.
output: Commitment. I commit to love this person through the worst and the best, through sickness and in health, through richer or poorer, and I commit to do my best to make our marriage successful. When commitment collides with compromise, our relationship gets deeper and stronger. We learn to listen to each other, compromise on everything and most importantly to understand each other. We make the choice to work hard to resolve conflicts when they occur so that love continues to grow and never subsides. A successful marriage is not a constant bliss. It's the commitment to go through all of it - joy and suffering, disappointment and celebration together that defines it's success.

Commitment. That’s right. It may sound silly, but it truly is commitment. We make a choice daily to fight for our marriage and put our spouse’s happiness above our own. Gartner uses the terms 4Vs to define the use cases that make business sense on Hadoop - "very large scale", "very high volume", "very fastquery", "very complex queries". Hive was built to solve the fourth V very complex queries by making SQL on HDFS possible, Pig was built to solve the second V very high velocity by enabling users to process large volumes of data quickly. Even today, Google still uses MapReduce as the core processing engine for its massive data sets although it uses Hive and Pig for SQL use cases. prompt: Does my data need to fit in memory to use Spark?
label: No. Spark's operators spill data to disk if it does not fit in memory, allowing it to run well on any sized data. Likewise, cached datasets that do not fit in memory are either spilled to disk or recomputed on the fly when needed, as determined by the RDD's storage level.
output:
No. Spark is designed to scale vertically and horizontally, meaning it can consume as much or as little memory as your workload demands, scaling easily from small to large-scale computing environments. This is particularly important when working with real-time data and in IoT applications, where the scale and amount of data is not easily knowable when initial design is started.

When executed locally, most of Spark's memory use goes towards caching in RAM (this is especially important if you are doing too many network hops). However, when executed on multiple nodes, some amount of data will need to be on disk per JVM - and depending on your setup and memory constraints, might still fit entirely in memory.

This is also not exclusive to local execution. No matter what the size of your cluster, when reading from or writing to a file, your RDD will have at least 1 iteration to read or write to disk before applying the caching behavior.

Because it runs on so many platforms in so many environment types, we aim for "good enough" performance with "minimal change" per platform. Hence instead of employing a more general case caching strategy where disk i/o's may still benefit from additional in memory

Traditionally, Spark's memory usage was proportional to the size of the dataset, which could lead to slower execution times especially when working with very large datasets. In Spark 2.x, improvements were made that reduce memory utilization and improve performance on large data sets.  A single node typically will only hold temporary data for a single task in ram. However this may be split across multiple files, depending on the configuration parameters.

No, Spark can scale to use both in-memory data and disk data. For small datasets, Spark can use Java’s garbage collection to manage the memory needed for the application, so you typically don’t need to call Java’s runtime to allocate extra memory for your Spark application.

No. Spark is designed to be scalable and will operate just fine atop disk storage. If the dataset fits in memory, then some jobs may be faster, but if it does not fit in memory, you will typically see better performance from Spark because it does not need to do as much I/O, which I/O-heavy operations can impact performance.

prompt: Give me some examples of Cockney Rhyming Slang and help me understand how it works.
label:
Cockney rhyming slang is a slang language originating from the East End in London, United Kingdom. It has a simple structure where a rhyming word or phrase is used in substitution of the word's true meaning. Examples:

Apples and pears = stairs
Adam and Eve = believe
Barnaby Rudge = judge
Bees and Honey = money
Dog and Bone = Phone
Hank Marvin = starving
Lady Godiva = fiver
output:
There are many variants of Cockney rhyming slang and new ones keep getting added or replace ones which are now out of date. This provides a flavour of some.

An example of a rhyming sequence could be
bait - trap
fair - hair
Fry - try
fly - buy
pale - male
rate - date
The next word to rhyme with "date" could be "mate" so the complete sequence would become
bait - trap
fair - hair
Fry - try
fly - buy
pale - male
rate - date
mate - late

Cockney rhyming slang is a slang language that was primarily used by East Londoners (also called Cockneys). The idea of the language is that words are replaced by other words that rhyme with them, e.g. instead of saying “I’m going to the shop,” a Cockney might say, “I’m off up the apple and pears to buy me a fare.” Fare is a Cockney term for money, hence the apple and pears rhyming with dollars. These sayings usually make a very basic sentence much longer and less sense so as to keep anyone but an East-Londoner confused about their intended meaning! In truth, it’s really difficult to explain this style of slang well in writing. Here are a few examples:
The chaps were playing cards: The flat-caps were playing cards.
Flat-caps are a traditional form of dress hat most usually associated with Northern England but more commonly seen on East Londoners who source them from the market.
The birds were at the gull; The girls were at the pub.
Though there are many varieties of bird known for stealing fish from the Gull’s

Cockney rhyming slang is a form of slang that originated with the East End of London's Romani community. Words are replaced by words that rhyme with it, either partially or entirely. It's usually funnier when used in a long sentence so that the last word is not expected to rhyme, for example, "Tesco's on tonight, innit. It's the old clinking up nose tonight. Let's get this peg-in-it-hole!"

Tesco's is grocery shopping (as Tesco's is a well-known brand) - innit is a form of contracted 'isn't it', the clinking up nose is a reference to an old London criminal nickname for a pick-pocket 'the Clone'); the peg-in-it-hole is a reference to needle and a record. As 'ole is already rhyming with 'nose', this final phrase doesn't rhyme exactly - Cockney rhyming slang is all about unexpected rhymes.

Cockney rhyming slang is a slang language that emerged in the East End of London, and is predominantly used by the old established orthochristian working class of Greater London. Most phrases use a series of replacement words (usually a noun) that rhyme with another series of words that also usually rhyme. Examples of Cockney rhyming slang include "Fanny up the apples, Fogarty's gone down his pants." "We only live once, mate. If only I had a brain cell then we'd have a better time." Or "Happy birthday to the queen. They took us to the Toby last week." Words can also appear to rhyme at first glance (example "steady" / "Ready", "papers" / "faders") but often don't, particularly when you try to repeat the rhyme out loud. Another factor of Cockney Rhyming Slang which can make it challenging to decipher its meaning is when two or more words rhyme within a short sentence that appears to have a single meaning. This can also lead to phrases where a sentence is repeated back which

prompt: What is the difference between mean, mode, and median?

Mean, mode, and median are statistics describing the central tendency of a distribution, but they are sensitive to outliers. An outlier can significantly change the Mean, for instance. prompt: What is geovisualization?
label:
Geovisualization or geovisualisation (short for geographic visualization), also known as cartographic visualization, refers to a set of tools and techniques supporting the analysis of geospatial data through the use of interactive visualization.

Like the related fields of scientific visualization and information visualization geovisualization emphasizes knowledge construction over knowledge storage or information transmission.[To do this, geovisualization communicates geospatial information in ways that, when combined with human understanding, allow for data exploration and decision-making processes.

Traditional, static maps have a limited exploratory capability; the graphical representations are inextricably linked to the geographical information beneath. GIS and geovisualization allow for more interactive maps; including the ability to explore different layers of the map, to zoom in or out, and to change the visual appearance of the map, usually on a computer display. Geovisualization represents a set of cartographic technologies and practices that take advantage of the ability of modern microprocessors to render changes to a map in real time, allowing users to adjust the mapped data on the fly.
output: A general view of geovisualization or, visual geovisualization, or VG is a technique of geography, and GIS analysis or Cartographic mapping that use 2D, 3D and Virtual Reality (VR) GIS, geovisualization or VG are map views whose rendering and analysis depend on the integration of: 1) Data/Place 2) Maps and GIS 3) Spatial intelligence and business knowledge 4) Time-series intelligence with geographic queries and advanced analytics

Geovisualization (sometimes geovisualisation, also known as cartographic visualization or geovisualisation) is an approach to visualisation that takes one or more types of geospatial data (e.g., digital elevation models, satellite imagery, population density data), geoprocessing results, any other location-referenced information, and creates insightful visual representations (typically in the forms of statistical maps or choropleth maps) that answer geospatial questions or display geospatial information of interest.[citation needed]

Geovisualization differs from other, more general styles of visualisation (e.g., those based on graphs or 2D or 3D statistics): its outputs are always defined in terms of space and (often, but not always) location of an object.[original research in doubt] The focus is on visualising geospatial information for an analytic or exploratory purpose, rather than for presentations; there is often a premium on high-level cartographic output, rather than low-level visualisation. For example, common functions such as 'where is it the warmest?', 'where are the largest clusters of ...?' cannot easily be answered

Geovisualization is an integration of various aspects of geography (topography, land use, climate, etc.) and visualization, using both historical and real-time data, to help users understand current events and make decisions. To achieve this integration, geovisualization applies user interface principles from visualization and geographic information systems (GIS).

Geovisualization or geovisualization analysis is a term used to describe the ability to analyze, manipulate, and visualize large sets of geospatial data using interactive tools such as globes, maps, 3D visualization, and virtual reality. It includes a range of techniques and technologies. The term Geovisualization covers a range of activities involved in studying geospatial data in a visually stimulating way.

prompt: Why do teenagers disappoint their parents?
label: Teenagers by definition are going through a process of maturation and individuation. They are finding their true self, distinct from their parents who have been their role model since infancy. Part of this process requires pushing boundaries set by parents. Parents often interpret this as disobedience and are disappointed. In fact teenagers who seem to be disappointing their parents are merely going through the healthy process of self identification.
output:
During the teenage years, it is quite normal for teenagers to go through many physical, emotional and psychological changes. These changes create conflicts between a teenager's inner desire for independence and the established bonds with family and society's expectations. As a result, teenagers disappoint their parents more than any other age group and in more than one ways:

Teens disappoint their parents by lying to cover up their activities that go against parental expectations. For example, some teens who know their parents do not approve of alcohol consumption still lie about going out with friends, who in reality are also drunk.  

Teens disappoint their parents by disregarding parental advice. For example, parents who keep telling their teenage kids to focus on their school work still find that their kids engage in distractions and waste time on social media instead.

Parents often struggle when their teens reject what was modelled and accepted as being right and good when that teen was younger. At age 16, 17 and 18, when their children undergo huge physiological, emotional and psychological changes as part of their growth from child to adult, they increasingly form their own opinions and, despite parents' protests, they follow their own paths - to which they believe to be correct. They think that their parents have been "uncool" when they were young and that the new generation knows it all. So as their children begin to diverge from their parents, parents usually feel disappointment and resentment.

During adolescence, a process that normally takes several years, the teenage child tends to gradually assert their independence from their parents. This can lead to typical behavior such as arguing with the parents, making decisions without asking or seeking approval, flunking a few grades in school, etc. As difficult as it may be for the parents, this process must be gone through. Only a generation later can a son or daughter tell their parents how they should act, how they should make decisions, which school is good enough, etc. There is no other way than through disappointing and worrisome behavior, even if only for a season, in order to lay the foundations for this independence. Only those who have disappointed their parents can protect and care for their own children in the future in a sufficiently independent and capable manner. Because at some point even the moms and dads have to give their children the space to assert their independence. This is a big topic in parenting and family science and is still the subject of extensive discussions among pediatricians, family physicians, and parents.

Teenagers go through major physical, emotional and social changes during adolescence which may not be communicated clearly or addressed satisfactorily to their parents, therefore cause some disappointment or conflict. According to psychologist James Dobson, teenage years can be 'The struggle is really with parents because they are still dependent on the stability of Mom and Dad. He has to get over his immaturity if he is to achieve emotional maturity which will set him for life'.

prompt: What is a stock?
label: A stock is partial ownership in a business.
output: Most people think of stocks as shares of common stock in a company.  Shares of common stock are representations of ownership in a company.  The more shares of common stock a company has, the more shareholders have a claim on the company's assets and profits.  Stocks can be issued by companies for a number of purposes.  They might be used to raise capital to fund company operations.  Once a company has raised money from its sale of stock, the shares will usually be traded on a stock exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange.  Buyers and sellers can then exchange shares for cash.

A company typically raises capital by selling ownership in it. A piece of that ownership is called a share. If you buy one share of Company A stock, you now own one bit of Company A and have a say in Company A through the vote that one share gives you. The aggregation of all of the shares of all of the various companies that are publicly traded is known as the stock market

A stock is partial ownership in a company. It represents fractional ownership in a business and makes you a part-owner of a company. In return for investment, businesses issue stock that represents partial ownership.

There are two main types of stocks: common and preferred. Common stock offers the investor full voting rights and makes them part of a company's decision-making process. Preferred stock does not come with voting rights but will get paid out first in the event of bankruptcy, after interest on any debt owed to shareholders is paid.

When a business needs to raise money to start or grow an operation, it can sell part of itself to investors in exchange for shares of stock. The owners of the business then have a ownership stake in the company. An owner of shares in a company is then referred to as a stockholder. When a company is ready to make money and wants to give it's shareholders some of that money, the company declares a dividend.

prompt: What is the stock market?
label: The stock market is the aggregation of buyers and sellers of stocks. Stock markets could include stocks on both public and private exchanges.
output: Typically, the stock market refers to the activity of sharing ownership of a company.  Stock represents partial ownership of a corporation and is typically represented by shares on an investor ledger with the corresponding company.  Stock can pay dividends at the discretion of the corporation and also enables an investor to have a voice within the corporation if they have sufficient ownership (typically over 10%).  In the stock market, investors can buy and sell shares of companies publicly traded on stock exchanges (i.e., New York Stock Exchange, or NYSE).

The stock market is an integral part of any economy. It allows companies, who want to raise funds, to list their shares on an exchange. Individuals and companies can then buy and sell shares in these companies, allowing for market-determined prices based on the company’s health, growth potential, and competition. 
In some cases the stock market also facilitates price discrimination in the allocation of capital, allowing more efficient use of resources. For instance, if a company has profits that it wants to use to expand capacity, issue dividends, pay off debt, make an acquisition or issue more shares for capital, it will need to keep track of that in the stock market. 
For companies listed in the stock market, a secondary market allows shareholders to trading shares of the company they have invested in. When a share is sold in the stock market, the proceeds obtained by the company are transferred to the seller's brokerage account, where they can be used to buy other securities, spend the money directly or keep it in an account ready for future purchases.
The stock market enables individuals, corporations, and governments to raise money for various projects by issuing and trading shares of stock.

The stock market is part of a company's economic engine that allows a company's assets (called shares of stock) to be transferred among investors.  The ownership of a company transferred among shareholders is the essence of the capitalist economic system that the stock market reflects.  Investors of stock may put money into a company at any time to allow the investor to be a partial or owner of a portion of the company.  The companies then can issue additional stock to take on new investors to also partake in the success of that venture.  The money generated by issuing stock in a company allows for investors to also reap the financial benefits of success in the company should they still own stock, or get paid as an original investor if shares are sold.

prompt: What is a pyroclastic flow?
label: A pyroclastic flow comes is created from a volcano that blasts out part of volcanic mountain into the sky.  It is a mixture of very hot volcanic rock, gases, ash and other trace elements that travels at hundred of miles per hour down the side of the volcanic mountain.  If you are in the way of a pyroclastic flow there is no escape and your life is in immense danger because of their temperature and mobility.  It is best to stay away from active volcanoes that could have a chance of developing a pyroclastic flow.  Pyroclastic flows have also been known to travel as far as 30 kilometers from the volcano.
output: A pyroclastic flow is formed by the rapid ejection of hot, fragmented lava and gases generated by a volcanic eruption. These type of eruptions usually occur in volcanically active regions or around a dormant volcano. Pyroclastic flows travels 5 - 65 km/h on average or 3 - 40 mph; but have been known to travel at speeds of 125 km/h or 77 mph, making them extremely dangerous because they are able to overtake people from the volcano regardless of the geography of the area. Because they carry extremely hot temperatures and spewing rocks and gases, the Pyroclastic flow becomes able to ignite fires far away from the original volcanic area. This has been known to cause burn injuries as well as to extinguish flora in areas where this type of ash is deposited; even for days later.

A pyroclastic flow is a current of hot gas and rock that moves down a volcano’s slope after a violent eruption. A typical pyroclastic flow moves at speeds ranging from 60 mph to 120 mph and can travel several miles from the volcano’s crater.

A pyroclastic flow occurs when a volcano erupts and is explosive. An eruption begins as typical when magma from beneath the volcano's summit comes into contact with the atmosphere and heats up, turning into steam. The blast of steam can erode the sides of the volcano and shoot out chunks of debris in all directions. The debris mixes with new volcanic ash, and because it is extremely hot it continues to erode everything around it. Because there is so much debris and it is traveling at high speed, a pyroclastic flow can cut through solid concrete and level entire cities.
A pyroclastic flow is a dangerous, fast moving current of hot gas and ash that travels down a volcano at speeds of up to 100 km/h.

prompt: What are some ways that I can reduce the latency of my API?
label: To reduce the latency of your API, you could consider caching any database operations you may have, reducing the number of network requests required, or scaling up the number of instances of your server.

There are several things that you can do to improve the latency of an API:
  - Use a fast language such as C, C++ or Rust instead of a language like Python. 
  - Avoid dependencies in your package manager. For example, for a C client, your Python package can simply use platform library calls.
  - Move your services or clients to machines that are closer to your customers, ideally on the same local network.
  - Make sure that your servers and load balancers have sufficient memory and are properly indexed to reduce the time it takes to find the right code to execute and for the client libraries to start executing your code.
  - Use an event driven mechanism instead of polling. Ideally, all systems will be updated in near real time so polling isn't actually needed, but your systems need to be able to handle out of order requests when they come in. Examples of event driven systems include Kafka or NATS.
  - When implementing load balancing between your servers, make sure to use an algorithm that takes into account the current network latency between each machine or data center and the load balancer.
There are several techniques that you can employ to reduce the latency of your API, such as reducing the amount of network requests and optimizing any algorithms used in your application.

There are a few ways to make your API less slow. Some of these involve caching or pooling database connections, which can reduce the number of database connections that need to be opened and closed. Others require more aggressive connection or instance pooling, or sharding. Another approach would be to increase server capacity.

If you have many small and fast nodes on a large network, consider moving any database that the nodes depend on to the lowest common ancestor of your nodes. This will reduce latency because database queries can be resolved without involving network hops. 

Consider using an existing content delivery network (CDN). This will probably require you to cache content that is retrieved frequently, and which is likely to change infrequently. 

Consider changing the network configuration of your deployment environment to optimize the number and placement of network hops between your consumers and your API.

prompt: Who were the Sumerians?
label: The Sumerian culture (3000-2350 BC) is regarded as humanity's first urban civilization. It originated in southern Mesopotamia, between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, and is related to Neolithic cultures, particularly the Uruk culture. They invented the wheel and writing, had a division of labor-based organization, and were incredible builders. Their Sumerian language is unrelated to any other known language. Sumerian is a cuneiform language, with ideograms, symbols, and abstract forms representing ideas rather than specific words or sounds.

Sumer was a region in southern Iraq which was inhabited by several distinct cultures known as the Uruk (Warka) period, from around 4500 BCE to 3100 BCE (calendare X). They are unrelated to the better known Babylonians and Assyrians (the ancient people of these later cultures called themselves Akkadian) with whom they eventually came to overlap in the 3100–2900 BCE (calendare XIX) period (the Uruk IV period), known as the ProtolLate Uruk or Early Dynastic I period). 

While known mainly from artifacts and literature, the Sumerian people themselves have left few physical remains. Scholars believe that they were either exterminated or merged completely with the population of Akkad, then replaced them, during the subsequent Assyrian expansions, from around 2500 to 2000 BCE (2500-2000 BCE, also calendars IX–VI)."

prompt: How do you know if you reached product market fit?
label: Product market fit, a term used by the startups ecosystem to identify if they have a product that satisfies a need for a number of customers for a problem they are currently facing. There is not a single unit of measurement if a startup reached product market fit or not. One of the ways to measure product market fit is if a startup is able to develop a repeatable sales process and are able to do basic forecasting for revenue. A product market fit is crucially important for the first product released by a startup but it’s also important for all upcoming releases of new products.
output:
There are multiple way to assess whether a startup achieved product market fit.  A couple of measurements could be :
* customer adoption
* customer feedback (is it very, very negative? or does it hint at minor usability issues?)
* competitive parity (is your offering better than alternative out there? are your differentiators resonating in the customer's mind?)
* Revenue / Bookings  (are customers paying you money?)
This can be measured over 3 key levers: the market, the product and the business model.

It is not always easy to measure if you reached product market fit, but the best indicators are when you are receiving an overwhelming amount of user feedback with zero to minimal pain points regarding the usage of your product and people are consistently asking about your product with excitement. Feedback mechanisms such as user surveys, customer interviews, and support tickets can show you whether there are bugs or things you need to fix to keep your product’s momentum up, but they won’t help you find product-market fit or determine your product’s momentum after a feature is built. If you’re receiving positive user feedback (both anonymous and via contact mechanisms), then there must be some latent demand that’s being served by your product or service.

You do MVP customer discovery and check if there’s any problem you found cannot be resolved with the current technology and requirements. Usually those are use case requirements, technology stack and delivery timelines related issues. If so, you’ve either under/oversold your product to the customer or your development bandwidth is too narrow or too wide. In either case you can gather customer feedback to confirm. There are more ways to measure it, it depends on your target and geo location.

There is no obvious indicator if you reached product market fit but few possible metrics that show that you're probably in product market fit:
* Customer retention
* The number of successful referrals from customers
* Customer's willingness to advocate for your product
* Net Dollar Retention (NDR) which is customer's total subscription amount at the end of a period divided by the total subscription amount at the beginning of the same period, is a metric that is tracking the subscription business customer's health and willingness to pay for the product.
* Total Revenue Growth (TRG) is the annual contract value (ACV) growth of the subscription business over the period. This is another good metric for tracking if you're probably in product market fit.

prompt: What is stream processing ?
label: Stream processing refers to techniques used to process a continuous stream of data. In batch processing, the amount of data is known up front when the processing starts. However, in stream processing, the computation (or query) runs ‘forever’ and as new data continues to get added to the input the computation updates its response.  To handle an infinite stream of data without needing to maintain infinite history stream processing queries often include the idea of windows which limits how much history is needed to be kept.
output: Stream processing is a computational model where data "streams" of continuous and heterogeneous data are processed on the fly. An example where such approach can be useful is to analyze the data while it is being generated e.g. network traffic, financial transactions, etc. The "slow" approach of saving the data somewhere, processing it at a later time is of course still possible, but since this data generation is often continuous the "real time" processing of such data gives competitive advantages e.g. detecting security threats, anomalies in the data as soon as it happens, etc. Stream processing can be done either online or offline, but offline will result in significant latency which may not be applicable for many use cases as I mentioned before.

Stream processing is a technique for processing continuous data in real time. Stream processing can ingest and manipulate huge amounts of real-time data in milliseconds. Stream-processing systems typically have the following components: source, sink, processing elements, and connectors.

Stream processing is a technique used in data processing and analysis that allows for the processing of data streams. Stream processing allows you to analyze real-time data or streaming data as it is being generated. There are multiple technologies across multiple ecosystems that have been developed that deliver stream processing - Apache Flink, Apache Spark's Structured Streaming, Beam, and Google's Dataflow.

Traditional relational databases are optimized for batch-based workloads but do not scale well for stream processing workloads which typically have low latency requirements. Often, the response time of relational databases for simple stream processing queries are hours, minutes or seconds depending on the size of the data and the complexity of the query.

Stream processing databases, on the other hand, are optimized for handling high volumes of incoming streaming data and provide very low latency response times. Stream processing frameworks can perform many different types of processing on streaming data. The specific type of processing depends on the nature of the data, the requirements of the organization attempting to process the data, and the type of database or other system with which the stream-processing framework will integrate. A stream-processing system must also handle missed or late data in a stream, as different sources will generate or receive data at different rates, and some sources (e.g. a log file) may emit data in bursts or with some degree of random spacing. As an example, a message queue may publish messages at a relatively slow rate and a database may insert messages at a relatively fast rate, so it is very important that a stream-processing system be able to ingest large amounts of data at high rate

prompt: How to find the area of a rectangle?
label:
A rectangle is a closed two dimensional quadrilateral structure with four right angles (90 degrees).  Opposite sides of a rectangle are parallel and of equal length. Usually, the length of longer sides is called length of a rectangle and the length of shorter sides is called width/breadth of a rectangle.

prompt: How do you push start a car with a manual transmission?
label:
1. Get the car to the top of a stretch of clear downhill road, or get people who will push you there.

2. Fully depress the clutch and put the car in second gear (first gear if you’ll be rolling slowly; choose the gear that you would normally use at that speed, and faster is better).

3. Turn the ignition to on.

4. Leaving the clutch fully depressed, take your foot off the brake and start rolling down the hill (or get people to start pushing you).

5. Coast down the hill until you reach 5+ miles per hour (faster is better).

6. Release the clutch quickly while giving some gas; the engine should turn and start. You may need to feather the clutch/gas to keep the engine running at first.

7. If it doesn’t start the first time, depress the clutch and release it again.

This can take some time and practice, but it is an excellent method to teach those who must frequently jump start their vehicles, such as taxi cabs.

6. Quickly turn the ignition and give it a bit of gas. If it didn’t start, do step 6 again
